conclusion: Several identical small steel balls are released every 0.1 seconds without initial velocity on an inclined plane.
A photograph captures multiple balls at different positions on the incline with AB = 15 cm and BC = 20 cm.
The scale of the photograph is 1:1 with the actual object.
The task is to find out how many small steel balls are rolling on top of ball A.
Balls are released at regular intervals of 0.1 seconds and roll down the inclined plane under gravity.
Their positions depend on the time since release and the acceleration due to gravity component along the incline.
Distance traveled by an object starting from rest and accelerating uniformly is given by s = 1/2 a t^2.
Time differences between consecutive balls are 0.1 seconds apart.
Assume ball A was released first, then B, then C.
Time since release of ball B is t - 0.1 seconds, and for ball C, it's t - 0.2 seconds.
Positions of balls can be expressed as s_a = 1/2 a t^2, s_b = 1/2 a (t - 0.1)^2, s_c = 1/2 a (t - 0.2)^2.
Using given distances, s_a - s_b = 15 cm and s_b - s_c = 20 cm.
Plug in expressions for s_a, s_b, and s_c: 1/2 a t^2 - 1/2 a (t - 0.1)^2 = 15 and 1/2 a (t - 0.1)^2 - 1/2 a (t - 0.2)^2 = 20.
